text: [Music]
love this is chef john from food wishes
dot-com big turkey wing gravy that's
right you can wait make gravy after your
turkey comes out of the oven as you're
getting everything else ready for the
Thanksgiving table but who needs all
that extra stress and aggravation that's
what your relatives are for so by making
your gravy ahead of time you can avoid
all that and not only have one less
thing to do right before dinner but it
will also probably come out better
because you have more time to give it
the attention it deserves ok so step one
we're going to roast our turkey wings in
a big roasting pan and that process will
start with some of this the mirepoix is
basically two parts onion one part
carrot one part celery do I measure of
course not
so some onions some celery some carrot a
little drizzle of vegetable oil just to
help things caramelize a little bit
alright we're going to throw two turkey
wings on top of that in case you didn't
know turkey wings make a great gravy
lots of connective tissue lots of flavor
and just enough fat which is what we're
going to use in the roux so this will be
a true gravy so we're going to go ahead
and pop that in a hot oven 400 degrees
for about an hour all right 45 minutes
to an hour you want it to be well
browned you want the vegetables be
nicely caramelized okay so it's going to
look something like that we're going to
transfer our turkey wings into a nice
large stockpot along with all that
caramelized mirepoix and of course the
reason you used a nice metal roasting
pan is we're going to add a splash of
water in here to deglaze the bottom so
just dump in a little water put the heat
on medium and just use a wooden spoon or
a spatula to scrape off that goodness
it's only going to take about two
minutes and when it looks like that turn
off the heat and pour it into your
stockpot to that we're going to add just
some regular plain cold water a few
sprigs of thyme and a couple cloves of
garlic I didn't even peel them I just
cut them in half all right at that point
go ahead and put your heat on high bring
this up to a boil as soon as it starts
to bubble like that turn the heat back
down to low because you know the drill
we want to back the heat down to low to
maintain a steady but gentle simmer and
we're just going to simmer that for
about three or four hours until that
meat completely falls off the bone and
basically if you pull the piece of that
meat out and tasted it it would be
virtually flavorless all that goodness
is going into the stock and by the way
during that three or four hours as you
simmer this on low
you want to take a spoon and you want to
skim off as much of that turkey fat as
possible for something to be a true
gravy it really needs to include some of
that animal's fat all right so if you
want a real turkey gravy you should have
a little turkey fat in it so I want you
to skim off as much of that as possible
you should easily get two or three
tablespoons alright so once you decide
your stock is done we're going to go
ahead and strain that you're going to
roughly end up with about six cups give
or take so right there our turkey stock
is done and we're ready for the next
step which is a roux but not just any
roux
we're going to put our heat on medium
we're going to throw some butter in a
saucepan like we usually do except to
that we're going to add our reserved
turkey fat and I'll give you the
measurements on the blog as usual to
which we're going to add about 1/2 cup
of flour and we're going to cook that
flour in that fat for a couple minutes
until it sort of smells like cooked pie
crust at that point you can turn off the
heat and you can slowly start whisking
in your turkey stock now generally we
like to do cold liquids into a hot stock
here it's okay the stocks still going to
be warm no problem just whisk the first
cup or so and slowly you should get any
lumps if you do big deal each strain
amount later but you really shouldn't
have a big problem and when you get that
first cup or two in it should look like
that and at that point you can turn up
the heat to medium-high you can dump in
the rest of your stock and bring it up
to a simmer now as you may remember from
other route based videos such as every
one of them as soon as your sauce or
gravy comes up to a boil that's
basically how thick it's going to be all
right so in my case I wanted to reduce
this a little bit to thicken this up a
hair all right I'm not looking for
Turkey pudding all right do you want
this to be a sauce so I don't want it
too thick so I simmered it for about
five more minutes until I had what you
see right there which in my opinion is
the perfect thickness and basically when
it has the consistency you want you are
done except for maybe the most important
part you're going to taste you're going
to adjust with some salt some freshly
ground black pepper and a pinch of
cayenne if you're doing an herb gravy
like rosemary or sage this is where
you'd add a little bit of fresh herb
really this is kind of a primal recipe
that you can adapt in a million
different ways so consider this a base
recipe
from which to work from and there you go
once it tastes how you want it to taste
your turkey wing gravy is finished and
here we go you ready for this
oh yeah no I did not have any turkey to
put this over I'm not making a turkey
like two weeks before Thanksgiving so I
just made some mashed potatoes for the
money shot and check it out I mean look
at that gravy flow slow and low that is
the tempo it's difficult to even begin
to describe how delicious this is and by
the way just because we're making this
ahead with turkey wings doesn't mean you
can't use those pan drippings from your
turkey pour them in here it's only going
to make it better but this will give you
a big head start like I said there's a
lot going on if you're like me you're
drinking a lot of beer trying to watch
football while you cook so the more
that's done the better so I really hope
you give this a try head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
